docs.snippet: An  obituary  on April 11 about the National Basketball Association executive and scout Marty Blake misspelled the given name and misstated the surname of an Italian player drafted by the Atlanta Hawks in Mr. Blake’s last year as the team&#...
docs.lead_paragraph: An obituary on April 11 about the National Basketball Association executive and scout Marty Blake misspelled the given name and misstated the surname of an Italian player drafted by the Atlanta Hawks in Mr. Blake’s last year as the team’s general manager. He is Dino Meneghin, not Deno Mengham.

docs.lead_paragraph: Accusations against four lawmakers have led to new anticorruption proposals and a need for distraction among the rank and file in Albany.
docs.abstract: Accusations of misconduct against four New York State lawmakers--State Sen Malcolm A Smith and Assemblymen Eric A Stevenson, Nelson L Castro and William F Boyland Jr--have led to raft of new anticorruption proposals and profound need for dark humor, stiff drinks and other types of distraction for many in rank and file.

docs.abstract: Prosthetic technology has advanced significantly over past decade, with computerized knees and ankles that adjust to terrain and activity; doctors know more about treating and salvaging limbs, making recovery faster than decade ago; advances will help those hurt in Boston Marathon bombings.

headline.main: War and Sports Shape Better Artificial Limbs

docs.snippet: John Kremer, a Navy explosives expert, lost both his legs below the knee after stepping on a mine in Afghanistan in 2010. In his San Diego hospital bed, he assumed he would be chained to a wheelchair for a year or more. Walking seemed a distant go...
docs.lead_paragraph:
John Kremer, a Navy explosives expert, lost both his legs below the knee after stepping on a mine in Afghanistan in 2010. In his San Diego hospital bed, he assumed he would be chained to a wheelchair for a year or more. Walking seemed a distant goal. Running? He could barely comprehend the concept anymore. 
 
But with the encouragement of therapists at the Naval Medical Center, Mr. Kremer was walking in two months, running in five and skydiving after nine. He did his first 10-kilometer race, about six miles, one year after stepping on the mine. Today he runs, swims or bikes almost daily and competes for the Navy’s wounded warrior team in swimming, shooting, seated volleyball and wheelchair basketball.
docs.abstract: Prosthetic technology has advanced significantly over past decade, with computerized knees and ankles that adjust to terrain and activity; doctors know more about treating and salvaging limbs, making recovery faster than decade ago; advances will help those hurt in Boston Marathon bombings. Photos (M)

headline.main: War and Sports Shape Better Artificial Limbs
